section.title: Treatment History [with entries]
section.text:
Admission to Community hospital for chest pain and transfer to tertiary care facility for angiogram Discharge Summary
Date of Admission: February 11, 2013
Date of Discharge: February 13, 2013
Reason: Subendocardial myocardial infarction/acute coronary syndrome
PREADMISSION COMORBIDITY: Allergic rhinitis /sinusitis.
This 66-year-old-lady was admitted through the hospital emergency department after having had spells of heaviness in the chest and arm tingling. This was initially not associated with any ECG change, but with a troponin rise of 1 increasing to 2. During the time of the hospitalization, she was treated with nitrates, low molecular weight heparin, Clopidogrel, and low dose beta blockade. Despite this, she had repeated spells of chest discomfort and wound up being placed on higher dose of beta blockade, transdermal nitrates. She developed inferior wall asymmetric T-wave inversion and did have transient ST segment depression with pain. Her case was discussed with Dr. Eric Fretz, and based on this discussion we did institute integrilin drip and Dr. Fretz made arrangements for transfer to the Royal Jubilee Hospital CCU for expediting angiography on the 13th of February. THIS DOCUMENT HAS BEEN DICTATED BUT NOT READ: Dr. VG Internist D: 13-feb-2013 22:00 T: 23-feb-2013 10:19 Transferred to Royal Jubilee Hospital

observation.text: THIS DOCUMENT HAS BEEN DICTATED BUT NOT READ

observation.value: Admission to Community hospital for chest pain and transfer to tertiary care facility for angiogram

observation.text: This 66-year-old-lady was admitted through the hospital emergency department after having had spells of heaviness in the chest and arm tingling. This was initially not associated with any ECG change, but with a troponin rise of 1 increasing to 2. During the time of the hospitalization, she was treated with nitrates, low molecular weight heparin, Clopidogrel, and low dose beta blockade. Despite this, she had repeated spells of chest discomfort and wound up being placed on higher dose of beta blockade, transdermal nitrates. She developed inferior wall asymmetric T-wave inversion and did have transient ST segment depression with pain. Her case was discussed with Dr. Eric Fretz, and based on this discussion we did institute integrilin drip and Dr. Fretz made arrangements for transfer to the Royal Jubilee Hospital CCU for expediting angiography on the 13th of February.
